title: Why were the Europeans interested in the spice trade? - Quora

response.answer_text: spice was one of the most precious commodity in the ancient world only procured from india and not available else where. europeans were tired of their tasteless cooking as well and wanted finer taste. indian merchants travelling to red sea made europeans acquainted and addicted to their spices. indian spices were expensive because of indian hegemony in the indian ocean as well and wanted to get them at cheaper rates. regards

Everything was fine until Mehmet II. When he conquered Constantinople. He increased the prices of Asian goods twice or even several times their old prices. But there was still a high demand. The Italians continued to buy and passed on the costs to the other Europeans. The Portuguese were encouraged to explore and increase their maritime skills by Prince Henry the Navigator. Who financed expeditions in exchange for 25% of the gross, detailed maps and logs. There was profit to be made by bypassing the Italians and Turks. By 1488 they discovered Cape of Good Hope South Africa. By 1498 they'd reached Calicut India. By 1513 they'd reached Guangzhou China.
